docs.lead_paragraph: The two main unions of Verizon Communications announced today that more than 75,000 workers had voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike if no contract is reached by Aug. 2. Verizon's largest union, the Communications Workers of America, said 92 percent of its 60,000 members working for Verizon in the Northeast had voted for a strike. The union, based in Washington, said the next step required for a walkout would be for the 20-member executive board to authorize the union's president to set a strike date.

headline.main: Union Votes Would Allow Verizon Strike

docs.abstract: Communications Workers of America and International Brotherhood Electrical Workers at Verizon Communications announce that more than 75,000 workers have voted overwhelmingly to authorize strike if no contract is reached by Aug 2; Verizon spokesman Eric Rabe says votes do not mean that strike will take place; Verizon is seeking more flexibility to lay off and transfer workers; also wants workers to pay higher share of health care costs; CWA is asking that Verizon agree to ways of making it easier to form union for almost 20,000 workers at Verizon Wireless (M)

Reischauer (Op-Ed, July 16): Mr. Reischauer is correct that the current Medicare proposals are unjust and place an unfair burden on state budgets. But his plea for equity and universality of Medicare does not go far enough. Medicare is fundamentally expensive, since it is aimed at the elderly, who are high-cost, high-use beneficiaries, while private insurance plans prosper by covering younger, low-cost, low-use members.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Tenet Healthcare hospital in San Diego was indicted by a federal grand jury today on charges that it illegally paid doctors to refer patients to the hospital. The indictment of the hospital, Alvarado Hospital Medical Center, had been expected since its chief executive, Barry Weinbaum, was indicted on similar charges last month. But the new indictment, which also names Mr. Weinbaum and supersedes the previous one, contains many more examples of suspected wrongdoing.

headline.main: Tenet Hospital Is Accused of Illegally Paying for Patient Referrals

docs.abstract: Tenet Healthcare's Alvarado Hospital Medical Center in San Diego is indicted by federal grand jury on charges that it illegally paid doctors to refer patients to hospital; indictment claims Alvarado paid more than $10 million for more than 100 physician-relocation agreements from 1992 to 2002; such agreements are supposed to be used to recruit doctors to move to community served by hospital; says Tenet arranged for substantial portion of money to go not to doctors being recruited but medical practices in Alvarado service area that they were joining; contends money was in exchange for patient referrals; Federal law prohibits payments to induce referral of any patients covered by Medicare or other federal health programs because such decisions are supposed to be based solely on best interests of patient; Tenet Healthcare says it will defend itself vigorously (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: General Motors reported a 30 percent decline in second-quarter net income today, in large part because of falling vehicle sales in North America coupled with a price war that continues to escalate. G.M.'s results were also hurt by $168 million in costs from a tornado in May that shut down the company's Oklahoma City assembly plant for nearly two months. The plant makes midsize sport utility vehicles like the Chevrolet Trailblazer.

headline.main: G.M.'s Net Income Declined 30% in Second Quarter

docs.lead_paragraph: If ever there was a case in which investors bought a boss, not a business, it came in the fall of 1986 when a sleepy lender to borrowers with not very good credit, known as Commercial Credit, went public. The boss was Sanford I. Weill, who had been ousted as president of American Express and rebuffed in what was viewed as a haughty offer to take control of the Bank of America when its fortunes were at a low ebb.

headline.main: A Climb to Riches, One Merger at a Time

docs.abstract: Market Place column on Sanford I Weill's decision to step down as chief executive of Citigroup focuses on how Weill through long series of mergers and acquisitions created global financial giant called Citigroup; says Weill took public Commercial Credit in 1986 and that company acquired others and went through names of Primerica and Travelers Group before merging with bank then called Citicorp; investor who put $10,000 at Commercial Credit's initial public offering, and who reinvested all dividends and distributions over years, would have had stock worth $334,349 at Citigroup's closing price on July 16 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The conference committee charged with fashioning a final Medicare bill convened this week amid signs that the differences between House Republicans and Senate Democrats are hardening. The main point of the bill was supposed to be providing prescription drug benefits to elderly Americans. But warring camps seem to be drawing lines in the sand around a much larger issue: a provision in the House bill that would force the traditional Medicare program to compete against private insurance plans starting in 2010. Many Republicans insist that such competition is indispensable to control costs. Many Democrats fear that the competition could ultimately destroy fee-for-service Medicare by driving up premiums and thereby pushing people into cheaper private plans. The task for the conferees is to bridge this widening gap. Otherwise Congress will miss the opportunity to give elderly Americans some of the aid with prescription drug costs that both presidential candidates promised in the last election.
